measured_by: scenario ratings of cloud height, visibility and likelihood to continue flight on a 9-point Likert scale after high vs. low anchors
justification: The authors state that pilots exposed to the high anchor "reported a higher assessment of cloud height…, visibility…, [and] likelihood of deciding to assess conditions as safe enough to continue the flight…" with the likelihood item "running from '1' = strongly disagree to '9' = strongly agree."

measured_by: number of disconfirmatory choices selected in weather-decision scenarios (chance level = 1.66)
justification: Figure 1 is described as "Confidence intervals for measures of confirmation bias in pilots…The horizontal line at point 1.66 represents the number of disconfirming choices expected by chance," indicating the construct was operationalised via counts of disconfirming options chosen.

measured_by: ratings of vicarious judgement, perceived risk and willingness to fly on a 1–9 scale after positive vs. negative outcome scenarios
justification: The critique notes that "When compared against the standard scale (running from '1', a favourable assessment, to '9', an unfavourable assessment), the effect of negative outcomes is apparent both for vicarious judgement (M = 6.02) and vicarious risk assessment (M = 5.96)."

measured_by: difference between own-flight safety rating and vicarious assessment on the same 9-point scale
justification: It is reported that "all groups reported their decision to fly to be safer than that of others (by 0.66 points … 0.85 … 0.57 points)"; this self-other discrepancy served as the metric of the illusion of control.
